Demystifying the Token Dynamics of Deep Selective State Space Models

Thieu N. Vo111National University of Singapore Tung D. Pham222FSoft AI Center, Vietnam Xin T. Tong333National University of Singapore Tan Minh Nguyen444National University of Singapore
Abstract

Selective state space models (SSM), such as Mamba, have gained prominence for their effectiveness in modeling sequential data. Despite their outstanding empirical performance, a comprehensive theoretical understanding of deep selective SSM remains elusive, hindering their further development and adoption for applications that need high fidelity. In this paper, we investigate the dynamical properties of tokens in a pre-trained Mamba model. In particular, we derive the dynamical system governing the continuous-time limit of the Mamba model and characterize the asymptotic behavior of its solutions. In the one-dimensional case, we prove that only one of the following two scenarios happens: either all tokens converge to zero, or all tokens diverge to infinity. We provide criteria based on model parameters to determine when each scenario occurs. For the convergent scenario, we empirically verify that this scenario negatively impacts the modelâ€™s performance. For the divergent scenario, we prove that different tokens will diverge to infinity at different rates, thereby contributing unequally to the updates during model training. Based on these investigations, we propose two refinements for the model: excluding the convergent scenario and reordering tokens based on their importance scores, both aimed at improving practical performance. Our experimental results validate these refinements, offering insights into enhancing Mambaâ€™s effectiveness in real-world applications.

1 Introduction

State space models (SSMs) have undergone significant advancements to mitigate the computational inefficiency associated with the sequence modeling [14, 17, 15, 16, 30, 24, 40, 48], and they have been successful applied in various domains involving continuous signal data such as audio and vision [10, 39, 47]. SSMs can be viewed as a combination of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs), drawing on concepts from traditional state space frameworks [23]. Unlike transformers, which experience quadratic scaling with respect to input sequence length and exhibit significant computational demands [51], SSMs are designed for efficient computation through recurrence or convolution, achieving linear or near-linear scaling as the sequence length increases. Furthermore, SSMs incorporate robust mechanisms for capturing long-range dependencies [13] across various data types, and they have excelled in benchmark tasks such as the Long Range Arena [50].

Selective SSMs such as Mamba is a particular SSM which involves the selective state-space layer (S6) as their core component [12]. In an S6 layer, parameters are functions of the input, endowing the SSM with the content awareness ability. Mamba has showcased exceptional performance across a variety of applications, such as language modeling [43, 32], image processing [34, 58], video analysis [56, 27], medical imaging [36, 53], tabular data analysis [1], reinforcement learning [41], point-cloud analysis [31], graph processing [52], and Nğ‘Nitalic_N-dimensional sequence modeling [29]. It has been argued that Mambaâ€™s significant success across various domains stems from its ability to compute complicated representations for different data types [21, 42, 54, 58].

Despite their remarkable empirical success, a thorough theoretical understanding of deep selective SSM is still lacking, which poses challenges for their advancement and application in high-fidelity tasks. As these models are scaled at a remarkable rate, understanding their internal mechanisms has become a major problem. In this paper, we take an initial step toward addressing this gap by analyzing the dynamical properties of tokens in a pretrained Mamba.

1.1 Background: Mamba

The building block of a selective state-space model is a Mamba block, which is built on top of the S6S6\operatorname{S6}S6 layers, along with linear layers, convolutions, and other token-wise operators. The S6S6\operatorname{S6}S6 layer, which serves as the core component of the Mamba block, plays a pivotal role in the success of these models.

1.2 Contribution

This paper aims to describe the dynamical properties of tokens in a pre-trained Mamba model. To achieve this, we consider the dynamical system governing the continuous-time limit of Mamba. The dynamical properties of tokens are described through the asymptotic behavior of the solutions of the dynamical system. Additionally, we empirically investigate the relationship between the dynamical properties of the tokens and model performance. In summary, our main contributions are three-fold:

  1. 1.

    In the one-dimensional case, we prove that only one of the following two scenarios occurs: either all tokens converge to zero, or all tokens diverge to infinity. We provide criteria based on model parameters to determine when each scenario occurs. Our experiments suggest that these observations generally hold in high-dimensional cases.

  2. 2.

    For the convergent scenario, we empirically verify that this situation negatively impacts the modelâ€™s performance. In contrast, for the divergent scenario, we prove that different tokens will diverge to infinity at different rates, thereby contributing unequally to the updates during model training.

  3. 3.

    Based on these investigations, we propose two refinements for the model: (i) we exclude the convergent scenario before training as it negatively impacts performance, and (ii) we reorder the tokens according to their ascending importance scores, as different tokens are prioritized unequally during training.

We empirically demonstrate the benefits of our token rendering method in improving the modelâ€™s accuracy and convergence speed compared to the baseline Mamba on the large-scale ImageNet classification task [7]

Organization of the paper

After surveying related works in SectionÂ 2, we introduce the dynamical system that governs the continuous-time limit of Mamba. In SectionÂ 4, we characterize the dynamical properties of tokens based on model parameters and determine the divergence rate in the divergence scenario. Based on the findings in SectionÂ 4, we propose two refinements for the model in SectionÂ 5: excluding unfavorable scenarios and reordering tokens before training. We conclude the paper with a discussion of conclusions and limitations in SectionÂ 6.

Notations.

We use small bold letters (e.g., ğ±,ğ²,ğ®ğ±ğ²ğ®\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y},\mathbf{u}bold_x , bold_y , bold_u) to denote sequences of tokens. Tokens can be either vectors or scalars, depending on the context, and are denoted by small normal letters (e.g., xi,yj,uksubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘˜x_{i},y_{j},u_{k}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), where the indices emphasize their position in the sequence. We use capital letters (e.g., X,Y,P,A,B,Cğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘ƒğ´ğµğ¶X,Y,P,A,B,Citalic_X , italic_Y , italic_P , italic_A , italic_B , italic_C) to represent matrices.

2 Related Work

Several studies have analyzed the expressivity and generalization of Mamba from a theoretical perspective. For instance, the authors in [2] demonstrated that the S6 layer can be interpreted as a variant of softmax-free attention with linear complexity, subsequently proving that Mamba is more expressive than transformers. Conversely, [5] employed tools from Rough Path Theory to show that diagonal selective state space models (SSMs), such as Mamba, possess less expressive power than their non-diagonal counterparts. Furthermore, [38] utilized circuit complexity theory to establish that both SSM variants and transformers share the same expressive power, as they belong to the complexity class Tâ¢C0ğ‘‡superscriptğ¶0TC^{0}italic_T italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which can be decided by polynomial-sized Boolean circuits. In contrast, the authors in [22] provided both theoretical and empirical evidence that transformers surpass state space models in their copying capabilities. All of these works aimed to provide a theoretical framework to understand the expressivity and generalization of Mamba.

In this paper, we examine the dynamical properties of tokens in a pretrained Mamba model. Following the methodology outlined in [8, 9], we define an idealized model of Mamba by interpreting the discrete layer indices as continuous time variables. This idealized perspective was used in ResNets [3, 18] and neural ODEs [33, 57, 28, 49, 46, 4]. Our model focuses on the S6S6\operatorname{S6}S6 layer, which is central to Mamba and contributes to its success across various domains.

3 Selective State Space Dynamics

In this section, we introduce the dynamical system governing the continuous-time counterpart of Mamba. This dynamical system will provide an effective tool to characterize the dynamical properties of tokens in Mamba as well as the impact of these properties on model performance in the next section.

3.1 Background: Continuous-time Limit of a Deep Neural Network

To ensure a clear presentation of our results, we draw upon the literature concerning the dynamical systems that govern the continuous-time limit of deep neural networks (DNNs). Generally speaking, data in a DNN is processed sequentially, layer by layer, resulting in a discrete-time dynamical system [26]. A notable example is residual neural networks (ResNets) and their continuous-time counterparts known as neural ODEs [3, 18]. Each layer of ResNet is a residual block, transforms an input vector xâˆˆâ„Dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ·x\in\mathbb{R}^{D}italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to an output vector zâˆˆâ„Dğ‘§superscriptâ„ğ·z\in\mathbb{R}^{D}italic_z âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT via a two-layer feed-forward neural network xâ†¦yâ¢(x,Î¸),maps-toğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğœƒx\mapsto y(x,\theta),italic_x â†¦ italic_y ( italic_x , italic_Î¸ ) , parametrized by Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸, and a skip-connection as:

There exists a body of work investigating the interpolation, approximation, and controllability properties of these DNN architectures [33, 57, 28, 49, 46, 4].

Similar to [8, 9], we have focused exclusively on S6S6\operatorname{S6}S6 layer, which is the key component of Mamba, and the skip-connection in the above dynamical system. These assumptions are primarily motivated by mathematical convenience. Nevertheless, such a weight-sharing mechanism is used in practice to reduce the number of trainable parameters, as seen, for example, in ALBERT [25], a transformer-based large language model. The dynamical properties of tokens in deep selective state space models with these additional layers will be discussed in future works.

We refer to this as the slow-divergence scenario (TheoremÂ 4.3). In the final scenario, one token diverges to infinity very quickly in finite time, causing a blow-up in the corresponding hidden attention scores. We refer to this as the fast-divergence scenario (TheoremÂ 4.4). TableÂ 1 summarizes the dynamical properties of tokens in this work.

Remark 1 (Convergence vs. divergence scenarios and their impact).

We collectively refer to the slow-divergence and fast-divergence scenarios as the divergence scenarios. By utilizing model parameters to test the signature of SCâŠ¤â¢SBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶topsubscriptğ‘†ğµS_{C}^{\top}S_{B}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can distinguish between the convergence scenario and the divergence scenarios. However, to distinguish between the slow-divergence and fast-divergence scenarios, additional information from the input data, specifically xl,0subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™0x_{l,0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is required. In addition, our experiments suggest that the convergence scenario negatively impacts model performance in practice, while the divergence scenario positively impacts model performance. Therefore, the convergence scenario should be excluded before training (see SubsectionÂ 5.1).

Remark 2 (Unequal contribution of tokens during training).

In the slow-divergence scenario, when tokens diverge to infinity at infinity, we further prove that tokens with different initial positions will have different rates of divergence. As a consequence, the contribution of tokens to the updates during model training is unequal. Intuitively speaking, the tokens should be rearranged in such a way that those carrying more important information diverge faster than those carrying less important information. In SubsectionÂ 5.2, we suggest a method for reordering the tokens before training by projecting them into a learnable line. Our experimental results show that this ordering method leads to better model performance.

Remark 3 (Higher dimension).

The extension of the above results to higher dimensions is nontrivial. In higher dimensions, SCâŠ¤â¢SBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶topsubscriptğ‘†ğµS_{C}^{\top}S_{B}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a matrix of size DÃ—Dğ·ğ·D\times Ditalic_D Ã— italic_D and may have complex eigenvalues. However, our experiments suggest that the above results still hold if we replace the condition SCâŠ¤â¢SB<0superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶topsubscriptğ‘†ğµ0S_{C}^{\top}S_{B}<0italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0 (respectively, >0absent0>0> 0) in the one-dimensional case with the condition that SCâŠ¤â¢SBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶topsubscriptğ‘†ğµS_{C}^{\top}S_{B}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is negative (respectively, positive) definite in the higher-dimensional case (see AppendixÂ B). We leave the study of the higher-dimensional case for future work.

In the subsequent subsections, we provide the statements of the main theorems. The proofs of these theorems can be found in AppendixÂ A.

Remark 5 (Unequally tokensâ€™ contribution).

TheoremÂ 4.3 shows that, in the one-dimensional case within this divergence scenario, tokens with higher absolute values will diverge to infinity faster than those with smaller absolute values (while all hidden attention scores still converge to zero). Intuitively speaking, this means that different tokens will contribute differently to the updates during training. Based on this observation, we conjecture that reordering tokens based on their importance scores before training might be beneficial for model performance. Our experiment in SubsectionÂ 5.2 empirically confirms this conjecture.

The proof of this theorem can be found in AppendixÂ A.2. We can intuitively see why the tokens tend to infinity slowly by looking at the values of the right-hand side of equationÂ (12). Indeed, let us assume that SÎ”<0subscriptğ‘†Î”0S_{\Delta}<0italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0 and thus xlâ¢0>0subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™00x_{l0}>0italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0. Then xlâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘¡x_{l}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) must always be positive as tğ‘¡titalic_t increases; otherwise, xlâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘¡x_{l}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) would reach zero at some point, and consequently xlâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘¡x_{l}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) would be identically zero for all tğ‘¡titalic_t, according to the uniqueness of the given initial value problem, which is impossible. As a result, the right-hand side of equationÂ (12) is always not too large. This implies that xlâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘¡x_{l}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) is decreasing. 5 Experiments

In this section, we empirically validate two key observations derived from the theoretical analysis presented in Section 4. We aim to (i) demonstrate the detrimental impact of negative eigenvalues in the input-output matrix SCâŠ¤â¢SBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶topsubscriptğ‘†ğµS_{C}^{\top}S_{B}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the performance of auto-regressive language modeling tasks and (ii) propose a reordering strategy and illustrate its effectiveness in vision tasks. We provide the details on datasets, models, and training procedures in Appendix C.

5.1 Effects of negative eigenvalues of input-output matrix

We use Mamba [12] as the baseline and conduct evaluations on the WikiText103 language modeling task [37]. We consider three distinct scenarios, including cases where the input-output matrix contains (i) only positive eigenvalues, (ii) only negative eigenvalues, as discussed in Section 4 and Appendix B, and (iii) both positive and negative eigenvalues as an intermediate case. The scenario where SCâŠ¤â¢SBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶topsubscriptğ‘†ğµS_{C}^{\top}S_{B}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT encompasses complex eigenvalues is deferred to future work. We report the perplexity (PPL) for each scenario. Lower PPL values indicate better model performance.

Scenario Perplexity (â†“â†“\downarrowâ†“)
Negative 17.26
Mix 16.84
Positive 16.71

Table 5.1 and Figure 4 illustrate the impact of different eigenvalue configurations on the modelâ€™s performance. Specifically, our findings demonstrate a correlation between the prevalence of positive eigenvalues in the input-output matrix and model performance. Conversely, the presence of negative eigenvalues is linked to a decrease in performance, suggesting that removing negative eigenvalues could further optimize the modelâ€™s efficiency.

5.2 Re-ordering input tokens

We now emphasize the significance of token ordering in vision tasks, where tokens naturally lack an inherent structure due to each token representing a patch from a 2D or 3D image. As indicated in TheoremÂ 4.3, the contribution of each token to model updates is primarily influenced by the term SÎ”â¢xlâ¢0subscriptğ‘†Î”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™0S_{\Delta}x_{l0}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a vector of dimension Dğ·Ditalic_D in a scenario with Dğ·Ditalic_D channels. To determine the optimal order of tokens xlâ¢0subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™0x_{l0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we define an importance score as follows:

sl=âŸ¨K,SÎ”â¢xlâ¢0âŸ©subscriptğ‘ ğ‘™ğ¾subscriptğ‘†Î”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™0\displaystyle s_{l}=\langle K,S_{\Delta}x_{l0}\rangleitalic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âŸ¨ italic_K , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© (14)

where Kâˆˆâ„Dğ¾superscriptâ„ğ·K\in\mathbb{R}^{D}italic_K âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a learnable parameter. Prior to passing the tokens through the S6S6\operatorname{S6}S6 layer, they are reordered based on their importance scores in ascending order. To ensure that the reordering process is differentiable, we utilize SoftSortSoftSort\operatorname{SoftSort}roman_SoftSort [44], which allows gradients to propagate through the sorting operation during backpropagation. Specifically, SoftSortSoftSort\operatorname{SoftSort}roman_SoftSort is employed to generate a permutation matrix, which is then applied to sort the slsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘™s_{l}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT array and rearrange the tokens xlâ¢0subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™0x_{l0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT accordingly.

To assess the effectiveness of our proposed reordering technique, we benchmark our method on the image classification task using the ImageNet-1K dataset [7]. We employ MambaVision [19] as the baseline and compare the top-1 and top-5 accuracy metrics.

The results presented in Figure 5 and Table 3 demonstrate that our reordering method speeds up the convergence of the training loss and improves the performance of the MambaVision baseline. These findings confirm the effectiveness of our technique in vision tasks, highlighting its potential for broader tasks.

6 Concluding Remarks

We characterize the dynamical properties of tokens in a pre-trained Mamba model. In the one-dimensional case, we show that either all tokens converge to zero or all tokens diverge to infinity. In addition, for the convergent scenario, we empirically verify that this scenario negatively impacts the modelâ€™s performance; therefore, it should be excluded from model training. For the divergent scenario, we prove that tokens at different locations will diverge to infinity at different rates, thereby contributing unequally to the updates during model training. Based on these investigations, we propose two refinements for the model: excluding the convergent scenario and reordering tokens based on their importance scores, both aimed at improving practical performance. Our experimental results suggest that these refinements do help improve model performance. Regarding limitations, our theoretical analysis of the dynamical properties of tokens is restricted to tokens with one feature channel. The extension of the results to higher dimensions is nontrivial. We leave the study of higher-dimensional cases for future work.

Ethics Statement

Considering the scope of our research, we do not anticipate any negative societal or ethical consequences emerging from this work.

FigureÂ 6 suggests that our results in the one -dimensional case may be extended to higher-dimensional cases with definite input-output matrices. However, this extension is nontrivial. We leave the study of the higher-dimensional case for future work.

Appendix C Experiment Details

In this section, we outline the experimental setup in detail. All experiments are conducted using a server with four A100 GPUs.

C.1 Auto-regressive language modeling

Dataset

We utilize the WikiText-103 [37], created from Wikipedia articles. It includes a training set of approximately 28,000 articles, amounting to 103 million words in total. Each article is split into sections of about 3,600 words. The validation and test sets contain 60 articles each, with word counts of 218,000 and 246,000 respectively, combining for a total of roughly 268,000 words.

Parameterization for three scenarios:

We outline the parameterization used to ensure the S6S6\operatorname{S6}S6 layer operates within the three scenarios described in Section 5.1. For the first two scenarios, we leverage the Lâ¢Dâ¢LTğ¿ğ·superscriptğ¿ğ‘‡LDL^{T}italic_L italic_D italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT decomposition [11] to ensure the positive or negative definite property of input-output matrix. Specifically, we parameterize SC=LTsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶superscriptğ¿ğ‘‡S_{C}=L^{T}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and SB=Dâ¢LTsubscriptğ‘†ğµğ·superscriptğ¿ğ‘‡S_{B}=DL^{T}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_D italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Dğ·Ditalic_D is a diagonal matrix and Lğ¿Litalic_L is a lower triangular matrix with diagonal values fixed at 1. In the first scenario, the diagonal values of Dğ·Ditalic_D are constrained to be positive and are parameterized as D=diagâ¡(softplusâ¡(dâ€²))ğ·diagsoftplussuperscriptğ‘‘â€²D=\operatorname{diag}(\operatorname{softplus}(d^{\prime}))italic_D = roman_diag ( roman_softplus ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ). In the second scenario, this constraint is reversed by parameterizing D=âˆ’diagâ¡(softplusâ¡(dâ€²))ğ·diagsoftplussuperscriptğ‘‘â€²D=-\operatorname{diag}(\operatorname{softplus}(d^{\prime}))italic_D = - roman_diag ( roman_softplus ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ), ensuring that the diagonal values are negative.

In the third scenario, both positive and negative eigenvalues are required, meaning that only complex eigenvalues are excluded. To achieve this, we set SC=SBsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶subscriptğ‘†ğµS_{C}=S_{B}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which guarantees that SCâŠ¤â¢SBsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ¶topsubscriptğ‘†ğµS_{C}^{\top}S_{B}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a symmetric matrix, thus ensuring that the eigenvalues are real.

Training details

We train a 130M parameters version of Mamba model [12] on WikiText103 for 25 epochs with GPT-2 tokenizer [45] and AdamW optimizer [35]. Other hyperparameters are set identically across three scenarios and listed in Table 4.

C.2 Image classification

Dataset

The ImageNet-1K dataset [7] is a widely recognized benchmark in the field of computer vision, commonly used for training and evaluating models on the task of large-scale image classification. It contains a collection of 1.28 million labeled training images and 50,000 validation images. Each image is labeled with one of 1,000 distinct classes, representing a broad variety of objects, animals, scenes, and more, allowing the model to learn a rich and diverse range of visual concepts.

Training details

We train the tiny version (31.8M parameters) of MambaVision model [19] with and without our token reordering technique. We follow the training procedure in [55, 20, 19] and set the hyperparameters for two cases identical, which is listed in Table 5.
